<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();
int[] indexes = random.ints(0, 10).distinct().limit(4).toArray();

for(int i = 0; i < indexes.length; i++){
    array1.add(images[indexes[i]]);
    array2.add(images2[indexes[i]]);
}
<<<explanation>>>: We generate 4 random indexes using the Random class. Then, we iterate through these indexes and add the corresponding images from both arrays to array1 and array2 respectively.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();
int[] indices = random.ints(0, 10).distinct().limit(4).toArray();

for (int index : indices) {
    array1.add(images[index]);
    array2.add(images2[index]);
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the Random class to generate random indices within the range of the arrays. Then, you can use these indices to get the corresponding images from both arrays and add them to separate lists.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();

for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++){
    int randomIndex = random.nextInt(10);
    array1.add(images[randomIndex]);
    array2.add(images2[randomIndex]);
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a random number generator to generate a random index between 0 and 9 (inclusive) and use that index to get the corresponding images from both arrays. Repeat this process 5 times to get 5 random images from both arrays.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();
int[] randomIndexes = random.ints(0, 10).distinct().limit(4).toArray();

for (int i = 0; i < randomIndexes.length; i++) {
    array1.add(images[randomIndexes[i]]);
    array2.add(images2[randomIndexes[i]]);
}

<<<explanation>>>: 
First, create two empty ArrayLists to store the selected images from both arrays.
Then, use the Random class to generate 4 distinct random indexes within the range of 0 to 9 (since both arrays have 10 elements).
Inside the loop, add the images at the randomly generated indexes from both arrays to the respective ArrayLists.
Finally, you will have 4 randomly selected images from both arrays stored in array1 and array2.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();

for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
    int index = random.nextInt(10);
    array1.add(images[index]);
    array2.add(images2[index]);
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a random number generator to select random indices from the arrays. In each iteration, generate a random number between 0 and 9 (inclusive) and use it as the index to retrieve the corresponding images from both arrays. Add the images to separate lists (array1 and array2) to store the selected images. Repeat this process 5 times to get 5 random images from both arrays.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: List<Integer> imagesList = new ArrayList<>();

// Randomly select 4 indices from the array
List<Integer> indices = new ArrayList<>();
Random random = new Random();
while (indices.size() < 4) {
    int index = random.nextInt(10);
    if (!indices.contains(index)) {
        indices.add(index);
    }
}

// Get the corresponding images from the first array
for (int i = 0; i < indices.size(); i++) {
    imagesList.add(images[indices.get(i)]);
}

// Get the corresponding images from the second array
for (int i = 0; i < indices.size(); i++) {
    imagesList.add(images2[indices.get(i)]);
}

// Convert the list to an array
int[] imagesArray = new int[imagesList.size()];
for (int i = 0; i < imagesList.size(); i++) {
    imagesArray[i] = imagesList.get(i);
}
<<<explanation>>>: The code randomly selects 4 indices from the array and adds them to a list. Then, it retrieves the corresponding images from both arrays using the selected indices. Finally, it converts the list of images to an array.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: 
List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();

int[] images = {R.drawable.a, R.drawable.f, R.drawable.k, R.drawable.u, R.drawable.y, R.drawable.w, R.drawable.t, R.drawable.g, R.drawable.b, R.drawable.o};
int[] images2 = {R.drawable.apple, R.drawable.fan, R.drawable.kite, R.drawable.umbrells, R.drawable.yark, R.drawable.watch, R.drawable.tap, R.drawable.gun, R.drawable.ball, R.drawable.orange};

for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
    int randomIndex = random.nextInt(images.length);
    array1.add(images[randomIndex]);
    array2.add(images2[randomIndex]);
}

<<<explanation>>>: 
To get 5 random images from both arrays, you can use the Random class to generate a random index within the range of the arrays' length. Then, you can add the corresponding images to the new arrays.

List<Integer> array1 = new ArrayList<>();
List<Integer> array2 = new ArrayList<>();

Random random = new Random();
int[] images = {R.drawable.a, R.drawable.f, R.drawable.k, R.drawable.u, R.drawable.y, R.drawable.w, R.drawable.t, R.drawable.g, R.drawable.b, R.drawable.o};
int[] images2 = {R.drawable.apple, R.drawable.fan, R.drawable.kite, R.drawable.umbrells, R.drawable.yark, R.drawable.watch, R.drawable.tap, R.drawable.gun, R.drawable.ball, R.drawable.orange};

for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
    int randomIndex = random.nextInt(images.length);
    array1.add(images[randomIndex]);
    array2.add(images2[randomIndex]);
